p:
Each of the components contributes to the unique properties of the gel. LiTFSI was used as it is soluble in water to a high concentration (when compared to Zn(TFO) 2 or ZnSO 4) to reach the water-in-salt regime. It is also used as a source of the [TFSI] anion since it is believed that the reduction of [TFSI] − is responsible for the formation of the passivating SEI, which extends the overall electrochemical window.
5, 7 We also note that in the absence of ZnSO 4 the gel is very sticky to handle, while in the absence of Zn(TFO) 2, a rigid dry material is formed, as excess ZnSO 4 pulls water from the mixture. The thermal decomposition of the gel electrolyte was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), which shows four mass losses due to the loss of H 2O (<200 °C), decomposition of [SO 4] 2– (200–284 °C, ∼10%), [TFO] − (323–450 °C, ∼34%), and [TFSI] − (>450 °C).
21− 23 The TGA also shows the gel contained about 15% water. The ionic conductivity of the gel electrolyte was determined using alternating current (AC) impedance ( Figure S1) and was found to be 6 mS cm –1, which is comparable to that of nonaqueous electrolytes (9.0 mS cm –1) used in commercial LIBs.
5 The electrochemical window of the gel, as well as the reversibility of Zn plating and stripping, was investigated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a glassy carbon (GC) disk electrode. The gel electrolyte exhibited fast kinetics for Zn oxidation/reduction and achieved a potential window of 3.0 V ( Figure 1 B), which is comparable to WiSE-based on 21 m LiTFSI.
